title: More House Hunters Buoy Prime London Prices
text:
A surge in demand for homes in prime central London buoyed sales prices in the city in August, according to a price index Knight Frank published on Wednesday.



Home prices in the city’s affluent neighborhoods—including Kensington, Chelsea, Westminster and the City of London—slipped 4.4% in August compared to a year ago, the mildest decline so far this year, according to the monthly index. Prices in prime outer London fell 3.4% during the same timeframe.

Increased demand amid tightening supply helped keep luxury home prices from falling further. The brokerage recorded a 29% spike in the number of house hunters registered with its prime central London branches in the 12 months through July compared to the previous year, the agency said.



Meanwhile, the market overall has recorded a significant drop in high-end supply. The number of new listings over £1 million (US$1.22 million) plunged 25% over the same time period, as sellers chose to wait out the political uncertainty surrounding Brexit.



However Brexit is negotiated, it’s unlikely to yield an immediate spike in new supply as developers have also chosen to wait out the uncertainty. Housing starts in London dropped to their lowest level in seven years in the second quarter of 2019—”underlining how the supply of housing is likely to remain a key issue in the capital,” wrote Tom Bill, head of London residential research at Knight Frank, in the report.



Interestingly, trophy homes have proved some of the most resilient in the British capital, where prices have fallen the least, 2.8%, for homes over £10 million.

Global demand for London’s priciest homes has helped bolster prices in that segment, particularly as foreigners capitalize on a severely weakened British pound. The average discount for buyers using a range of overseas currencies is roughly 25% compared to early 2016, before Britain’s vote to exit the European Union.



“The discount has widened in recent weeks,” Mr. Bill wrote, “as political uncertainty rises in the U.K.”
